docTitle.titlePart: by EMILY DICKINSON Third Series Edited by MABEL LOOMIS TODD It 's all I have to bring to-day , This , and my heart beside , This , and my heart , and all the fields , And all the meadows wide . Be sure you count , should I forget , — Some one the sum could tell , — This , and my heart , and all the bees Which in the clover dwell .

div.head: PREFACE .
div.p: The intellectual activity of Emily Dickinson was so great that a large and characteristic choice is still possible among her literary material , and this third volume of her verses is put forth in response to the repeated wish of the admirers of her peculiar genius . Much of Emily Dickinson 's prose was rhythmic , — even rhymed , though frequently not set apart in lines .

Also many verses , written as such , were sent to friends in letters ; these were published in 1894 , in the volumes of her Letters . It has not been necessary , however , to include them in this Series , and all have been omitted , except three or four exceptionally strong ones , as “ A Book , ” and “ With Flowers . ”

There is internal evidence that many of the poems were simply spontaneous flashes of insight , apparently unrelated to outward circumstance . Others , however , had an obvious personal origin ; for example , the verses “ I had a Guinea golden , ” which seem to have been sent to some friend travelling in Europe , as a dainty reminder of letter-writing delinquencies . The surroundings in which any of Emily Dickinson 's verses are known to have been written usually serve to explain them clearly ; but in general the present volume is full of thoughts needing no interpretation to those who apprehend this scintillating spirit .

lg.l: ‘ T is little I could care for pearls
Or gold , who am the Prince of Mines ;
A diadem to fit a dome
‘ T is not conferred by any ,

lg.head: I .
lg.l: How luscious lies the pea within
Heaven is what I cannot reach !
The color on the cruising cloud ,
Behind the hill , the house behind , —
To invest existence with a stately air ,
It 's such a little thing to weep ,
So short a thing to sigh ;
And yet by trades the size of these
Three times , ‘ t is said , a sinking man
Comes up to face the skies ,
Where hope and he part company , —
For he is grasped of God .
Is shunned , we must admit it ,
How still the bells in steeples stand ,
They leap upon their silver feet
If the foolish call them ‘ flowers , ’
Those who read the same edition
Could we stand with that old Moses
Scan , like him , the stately landscape
Low amid that glad Belles lettres

lg.head: A SYLLABLE .
lg.l: ‘ T would crumble with the weight .
My life closed twice before its close ;
So huge , so hopeless to conceive ,
Parting is all we know of heaven ,
And all we need of hell .
We never know how high we are
Till we are called to rise ;
And then , if we are true to plan ,
Did not ourselves the cubits warp
For fear to be a king .

lg.head: THE INEVITABLE .
lg.l: While I was fearing it , it came ,
But came with less of fear ,
Because that fearing it so long
There is a fitting a dismay ,
‘ Tis harder knowing it is due ,
There is no frigate like a book
Nor any coursers like a page
This traverse may the poorest take
Who has not found the heaven below
God 's residence is next to mine ,

lg.head: A PORTRAIT .
lg.l: A face devoid of love or grace ,
A face with which a stone
Would feel as thoroughly at ease
I lost it in the sand ,
And though the sum was simple ,
And pounds were in the land ,
Still had it such a value
That when I could not find it
I sat me down to sigh .
Who sang full many a day ,
But when the woods were painted
I kept the ‘ house at hame . ’
I had a star in heaven ;
And when I was not heeding
And though the skies are crowded ,
I do not care about it ,
Since none of them are mine .
Shall meet the eye of traitor

body.p: NOTE . — This poem may have had , like many others , a personal origin . It is more than probable that it was sent to some friend travelling in Europe , a dainty reminder of letter-writing delinquencies .

lg.l: From all the jails the boys and girls
They storm the earth and stun the air ,
Alas ! that frowns could lie in wait
For such a foe as this !
Few get enough , — enough is one ;
Have not each one of us the right
Upon the gallows hung a wretch ,
To which the law entitled him .
The one who bore him tottered in ,
‘'T was all I had , ’ she stricken gasped ;
I felt a clearing in my mind
As if my brain had split ;
I tried to match it , seam by seam ,
But could not make them fit .
The thought behind I strove to join
But sequence ravelled out of reach
If nature will not tell the tale
And if to miss were merry ,
And if to mourn were gay ,
The farthest thunder that I heard
And rumbles still , though torrid noons
But I would not exchange the bolt
For all the rest of life .
It founds the homes and decks the days ,
The thought is quiet as a flake , —
On the bleakness of my lot
Late , my acre of a rock
Soil of flint if steadfast tilled
Seed of palm by Lybian sun
A door just opened on a street —
An instant 's width of warmth disclosed ,
The door as sudden shut , and I ,
Lost doubly , but by contrast most ,
Fire exists the first in light ,
Fate slew him , but he did not drop ;
She felled — he did not fall —
Impaled him on her fiercest stakes —
She stung him , sapped his firm advance ,
But , when her worst was done ,

lg.head: VENTURES .
lg.l: Finite to fail , but infinite to venture .
For the one ship that struts the shore
I measure every grief I meet
I wonder if it weighs like mine ,
I wonder if they bore it long ,
I could not tell the date of mine ,
It feels so old a pain .
I wonder if it hurts to live ,
And if they have to try ,
And whether , could they choose between ,
I wonder if when years have piled —
Of early hurt , if such a lapse
Or would they go on aching still
The grieved are many , I am told ;
Death is but one and comes but once ,
There 's grief of want , and grief of cold , —
And though I may not guess the kind
To note the fashions of the cross ,
That some are like my own .
I have a king who does not speak ;
So , wondering , thro ’ the hours meek
Half glad when it is night and sleep ,
If , haply , thro ’ a dream to peep
And if I do , when morning comes ,
It is as if a hundred drums
And shouts fill all my childish sky ,
And if I do n't , the little Bird
Within the Orchard is not heard ,
‘ Father , thy will be done ’ to-day ,
For my will goes the other way ,
It dropped so low in my regard
I heard it hit the ground ,
And go to pieces on the stones
Yet blamed the fate that fractured , less
Till sudden I perceived it stir , —
I worked for chaff , and earning wheat
What right had fields to arbitrate
I tasted wheat , — and hated chaff ,
Minor apparatus , hopper of the mill ,
Remembrance has a rear and front , —
‘ T is something like a house ;
Look to it , by its fathoms
That such was not the posture
That , in so dense a fuzz ,
The brain is wider than the sky ,
For , put them side by side ,
The one the other will include
The brain is deeper than the sea ,
For , hold them , blue to blue ,
The one the other will absorb ,
The brain is just the weight of God ,
For , lift them , pound for pound ,
And they will differ , if they do ,
The bone that has no marrow ;
It is not fit for table ,
The past is such a curious creature ,
To look her in the face
Which if they do not fit for earth
One would as soon assault a plush
Within its hope , though yet ungrasped

lg.head: PHILOSOPHY .
lg.l: To fail with land in sight ,
You cannot put a fire out ;
Can go , itself , without a fan
And put it in a drawer , —
Because the winds would find it out ,
A modest lot , a fame petite ,
A brief campaign of sting and sweet
A sailor 's business is the shore ,
A soldier 's — balls . Who asketh more
I must not put my foot amiss
For fear I spoil my shoe ?
For yet to buy another pair
But bliss is sold just once ;
I stepped from plank to plank
The stars about my head I felt ,
I knew not but the next
This gave me that precarious gait
One day is there of the series
Seems it , to my hooded thinking ,
Had there been no sharp subtraction
Not an acre or a caption
Not a mention , whose small pebble

lg.head: CONSECRATION .
lg.l: Proud of my broken heart since thou didst break it ,
Proud of the pain I did not feel till thee ,
Proud of my night since thou with moons dost slake it ,
Not to partake thy passion , my humility .
My worthiness is all my doubt ,
Conform my soul as ‘ t were a church
One blessing had I , than the rest
It was the limit of my dream ,
I knew no more of want or cold ,
For this new value in the soul ,
The heaven below the heaven above
Why floods are served to us in bowls , —
When roses cease to bloom , dear ,
The hand that paused to gather
Summer for thee grant I may be
For thee to bloom , I 'll skip the tomb
Split the lark and you 'll find the music ,
Bulb after bulb , in silver rolled ,
Scantily dealt to the summer morning ,
Saved for your ear when lutes be old .
Loose the flood , you shall find it patent ,
Gush after gush , reserved for you ;
Now , do you doubt that your bird was true ?
To lose thee , sweeter than to gain
‘ T is true the drought is destitute ,
But then I had the dew !
The Caspian has its realms of sand ,

body.p: Poor little heart ! Did they forget thee ? Then dinna care ! Then dinna care !
Proud little heart ! Did they forsake thee ? Be debonair ! Be debonair !

lg.l: Could'st credit me ? Could'st credit me ?
Thou 'll wilted be ; thou 'll wilted be !
Loving the hand that sent it ,
Fell , they will say , in ‘ skirmish ’ !
Before they drop full music on ;
Your breath has time to straighten ,
You may forget the warmth he gave ,
When you have done , pray tell me ,
That I my thoughts may dim ;
Father , I bring thee not myself , —
I bring thee the imperial heart
I had not strength to hold .
The heart I cherished in my own
Yet strangest , heavier since it went ,
Is it too large for you ?
We outgrow love like other things
And put it in the drawer ,
Till it an antique fashion shows
Not with a club the heart is broken ,
A whip , so small you could not see it .
Yet that whip 's name too noble
My friend must be a bird ,
Barbs has it , like a bee .
He touched me , so I live to know
That such a day , permitted so ,
It was a boundless place to me ,
And silenced , as the awful sea
And now , I 'm different from before ,
As if I breathed superior air ,
My feet , too , that had wandered so ,

lg.head: DREAMS .
lg.l: Let me not mar that perfect dream
But so adjust my daily night
I live with him , I see his face ;
And that by right that he
I live with him , I hear his voice ,
Taught me by Time , — the lower way ,
That life like this is endless ,
I envy seas whereon he rides ,
The wealthy fly upon his pane ,
I envy light that wakes him ,
To tell him it is noon abroad , —
A solemn thing it was , I said ,
And wear , if God should count me fit ,
A timid thing to drop a life
Too plummetless that it come back
The lilacs , bending many a year ,
The bees will not forget the tune
The rose will redden in the bog ,
Upon the furthest slope we know ;
A lady red upon the hill
A lady white within the field
The tidy breezes with their brooms
Sweep vale , and hill , and tree !
The neighbors do not yet suspect !
And yet how still the landscape stands ,
How out of breath you are !
Oh , March , come right upstairs with me ,
I have so much to tell !
I got your letter , and the birds ’ ;
That you were coming , — I declare ,
You left for me to hue ;
You took it all with you .
He stayed away a year , to call
As soon as you have come ,
That blame is just as dear as praise
And praise as mere as blame .

lg.head: MARCH .
lg.l: We like March , his shoes are purple ,
Makes he mud for dog and peddler ,
Knows the adder 's tongue his coming ,
Stands the sun so close and mighty
News is he of all the others ;
Not knowing when the dawn will come
Or has it feathers like a bird ,
A murmur in the trees to note ,
A star not far enough to seek ,
A long , long yellow on the lawn ,
Not audible , as ours to us ,
A hurrying home of little men
All this , and more , if I should tell ,
Of robins in the trundle bed
Whose nightgowns could not hide the wings ,
But then I promised ne'er to tell ;
How could I break my word ?
So go your way and I 'll go mine , —
No fear you 'll miss the road .
Morning is the place for dew ,
To my quick ear the leaves conferred ;
I could not find a privacy
In cave if I presumed to hide ,
A sepal , petal , and a thorn
A flash of dew , a bee or two ,
High from the earth I heard a bird ;
And then he spied a breeze ,
I take thee by the hand .
The grass does not appear afraid ;
Can stand so close and look so bold
At what is dread to me .
The sedge stands next the sea ,
Where he is floorless , yet of fear
But nature is a stranger yet ;
The ones that cite her most
Have never passed her haunted house ,
To pity those that know her not
That those who know her , know her less
To make a prairie it takes a clover and one bee , —
And felt , ‘ how vast a destiny !
The sun went out to work ,
The day went out to play ,
But not again that dew was seen

lg.head: THE WOODPECKER .
lg.l: His head , a cap and frill .
Sweet is the swamp with its secrets ,
‘ T is then we sigh for houses ,
And guile is where it goes .
And visit only where I liked ,
And flirt all day with buttercups ,
Or chase me if I do ,
I said , but just to be a bee
And row in nowhere all day long ,
The moon was but a chin of gold
And now she turns her perfect face
Her forehead is of amplest blond ;
Her eye unto the summer dew
Her lips of amber never part ;
But what must be the smile
Upon her friend she could bestow
And what a privilege to be
For certainly her way might pass
The stars the trinkets at her belt ,
The bat is dun with wrinkled wings
And not a song pervades his lips ,
You 've seen balloons set , have n't you ?
It is as swans discarded you
Their liquid feet go softly out
They spurn the air as ‘ t were too mean
Their ribbons just beyond the eye ,
And yet the crowd applauds below ;
The gilded creature strains and spins ,
The crowd retire with an oath
The dust in streets goes down ,
And workmen finished , one by one ,
The low grass loaded with the dew ,
The twilight stood as strangers do
With hat in hand , polite and new ,
To stay as if , or go .
A vastness , as a neighbor , came , —
A wisdom without face or name ,
A peace , as hemispheres at home , —

lg.head: SUNSET .
lg.l: A sloop of amber slips away
And wrecks in peace a purple tar ,
How the old mountains drip with sunset ,
How the hemlocks are tipped in tinsel
How the old steeples hand the scarlet ,
Have I the lip of the flamingo
Then , how the fire ebbs like billows ,
How a small dusk crawls on the village
And the odd flambeaux no men carry
Now it is night in nest and kennel ,
Just a dome of abyss is nodding
These are the visions baffled Guido ;
The murmuring of bees has ceased ;
The lower metres of the year ,
And through a riddle , at the last ,
To gain it , men have shown
Time is a test of trouble ,
If such it prove , it prove too
Not that we tire of thee ,
But that thyself fatigue of us ;
To con thee o'er and o'er ,
If thou would'st take it now .
That is solemn we have ended , —
Or a glee among the garrets ,
Or a leaving home ; or later ,
Bride of the Father and the Son ,
Only the keeper of this seal
That such have died enables us
They wo n't frown always , — some sweet day
They 'll recollect how cold I looked ,
And how I just said ‘ please . ’
Then they will hasten to the door
Who cannot thank them , for the ice
And makes one lift one 's hat ,
The distance that the dead have gone
And then , that we have followed them
Who since they went to their account
Paid all that life had earned
And now , what life or death can do
Whose garden wrestles with the dew ,
Ring the tree and leave it , —
‘ T is sunrise , little maid , hast thou
‘ T was not thy wont to hinder so , —
‘ T is noon , my little maid , alas !
The lily waiting to be wed ,
My little maid , ‘ t is night ; alas ,
That night should be to thee
Instead of morning ! Hadst thou broached
Dissuade thee if I could not , sweet ,
Each that we lose takes part of us ;
Which like the moon , some turbid night ,
Not any higher stands the grave
Not any nearer for the child
As far from pity as complaint ,
As cool to speech as stone ,
As if my trade were bone .
As far from time as history ,
As children to the rainbow 's scarf ,
‘ T is whiter than an Indian pipe ,
‘ T is dimmer than a lace ;
No stature has it , like a fog ,
Not any voice denotes it here ,
A spirit , how doth it accost ?
Each one of us shall be ;
She laid her docile crescent down ,
Still states , to dates that have forgot ,
The news that she is gone .
So constant to its stolid trust ,
It shames the constancy that fled
Bless God , he went as soldiers ,
Grant , God , he charge the bravest
Please God , might I behold him
I should not fear the foe then ,
I should not fear the fight .
When what we need is by ,
But when it leaves us for a time ,
Of heaven above the firmest proof
Where every bird is bold to go ,
The grave my little cottage is ,
This was in the white of the year ,
Drifts were as difficult then to think
As daisies now to be seen .
Looking back is best that is left ,
Within its precincts hopes have played , —
From us she wandered now a year ,
No eye hath seen and lived ,
We only know what time of year
I wish I knew that woman 's name ,
So , when she comes this way ,
To hold my life , and hold my ears ,
For fear I hear her say
She 's ‘ sorry I am dead , ’ again ,
Just when the grave and I
Have sobbed ourselves almost to sleep , —
Bereaved of all , I went abroad ,
And when I sought my bed ,
The grave it was , reposed upon
I waked , to find it first awake ,
I tried to drop it in the crowd ,
To lose it in the sea ,
The grave was finished , but the spade
I felt a funeral in my brain ,
Kept treading , treading , till it seemed
And when they all were seated ,
Kept beating , beating , till I thought
And then I heard them lift a box ,
With those same boots of lead , again .
As all the heavens were a bell ,
And I and silence some strange race ,
I meant to find her when I came ;
But the success was his , it seems ,
I meant to tell her how I longed
But Death had told her so the first ,
To wander now is my abode ;
To rest , — to rest would be
I sing to use the waiting ,
And shut the door unto my house ;
No more to do have I ,
And tell each other how we sang
A sickness of this world it most occasions
And whose ‘ I 'll meet you ’ hesitates
So proud she was to die
That what we cherished , so unknown
Where none of us should be ,
Tie the strings to my life , my Lord ,
Then I am ready to go !
Just a look at the horses —
Put me in on the firmest side ,
For we must ride to the Judgment ,
But never I mind the bridges ,
And never I mind the sea ;
By my own choice and thee .
Good-by to the life I used to live ,
And the world I used to know ;
And kiss the hills for me , just once ;
Now I am ready to go !
The dying need but little , dear , —
A fan , perhaps , a friend 's regret ,
It wears a sprig upon its breast ,
And will not tell its name .
Some touch it and some kiss it ,
The soul should always stand ajar ,
He will not be obliged to wait ,
Depart , before the host has slid
To seek for the accomplished guest , —
Three weeks passed since I had seen her , —
‘ T was with text and village singing
Gracious now to me as any ,
I breathed enough to learn the trick ,
I simulate the breath so well ,
That one , to be quite sure
The lungs are stirless , must descend
When men and boys , and larks and June
Go down the fields to hay !
If tolling bell I ask the cause .
‘ A soul has gone to God , ’
I 'm answered in a lonesome tone ;
That bells should joyful ring to tell
A soul had gone to heaven ,
Would seem to me the proper way
A good news should be given .
If I may have it when it 's dead
If just as soon as breath is out
Until they lock it in the grave ,
‘ T is bliss I cannot weigh ,
For though they lock thee in the grave ,
Think of it , lover ! I and thee
Permitted face to face to be ;
After a life , a death we 'll say , —
For death was that , and this is thee .
Before the ice is in the pools ,
What we touch the hems of
That which sings so , speaks so ,
Will the frock I wept in
I heard a fly buzz when I died ;
Was like the stillness in the air
The eyes beside had wrung them dry ,
For that last onset , when the king
I willed my keepsakes , signed away
And then the windows failed , and then
I could not see to see .
Will no one guide a little boat
Just as the dusk was brown ,
One little boat gave up its strife ,
Just as the dawn was red ,
One little boat o'erspent with gales
Retrimmed its masts , redecked its sails
There 's been a death in the opposite house
I know it by the numb look
The neighbors rustle in and out ,
A window opens like a pod ,
They wonder if It died on that , —
I used to when a boy .
As if the house were his ,
And he owned all the mourners now ,
And then the milliner , and the man
To take the measure of the house .
Of tassels and of coaches soon ;
We never know we go , — when we are going
We jest and shut the door ;
Fate following behind us bolts it ,
As if the cloud that instant slit
It burned me in the night ,
It sickened fresh upon my sight
I thought that storm was brief , —
But Nature lost the date of this ,
And left it in the sky .
We thirst at first , — ‘ t is Nature 's act ;
Is that great water in the west
A clock stopped — not the mantel 's ;
Ca n't put the puppet bowing
An awe came on the trinket !
It will not stir for doctors ,
The little cage of ‘ Currer Bell , ’
Yet not in all the nests I meet
Soft fall the sounds of Eden
Oh , what an afternoon for heaven ,
A toad can die of light !
Far from love the Heavenly Father
Oftener by the claw of dragon
A long , long sleep , a famous sleep
That makes no show for dawn
By stretch of limb or stir of lid , —
Nor once look up for noon ?
‘ T was just this time last year I died .
I know I heard the corn ,
When I was carried by the farms , —
I thought how yellow it would look
And then I wanted to get out ,
I thought just how red apples wedged
And carts went stooping round the fields
I wondered which would miss me least ,
And if my stocking hung too high ,
Would it blur the Christmas glee ,
That not a Santa Claus could reach
But this sort grieved myself , and so
I thought how it would be
When just this time , some perfect year ,
